name: Cumbia
description: Danceable folk genre formed during the 19th century in Colombia and eastern Panama.

children.name: Cumbia argentina
children.description: Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

children.name: Cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.

children.name: Cumbia colombiana
children.description: Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

children.name: Cumbia mexicana
children.description: Incorporation of Rock & Roll, Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.

children.name: Cumbia peruana
children.description: Developed in Peru and diversified into various subgenres, each with its own regional influences.

children.name: Cumbia pop
children.description: Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.

children.name: Cumbia salvadoreña
children.description: Takes influence from local Salvadoran music and traditionally features a distinctive ensemble.

children.name: Digital Cumbia
children.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

children.name: Merecumbé
children.description: Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.
